body.p: This chapter describes how to install the WaveReady Node Manager (WRNM).
This chapter contains the following sections:

li.xref: System Requirements on page 3-1
Installing Node Manager on page 3-2
Launching Node Manager on page 3-10
Troubleshooting and Related Information on page 3-17

body.p: This section describes the system requirements for installing the Node Manager application.
This section contains the following topics:

li.xref: Standard System Requirements on page 3-1
JWS Web Server Requirements on page 3-2
JWS Client Requirements on page 3-2

body.p: The computer used to host Node Manager sessions must meet these minimum system requirements:

ul.li: Pentium III or better (600 MHz or better)
Display set to 1024 x 768 pixels (or more) and 256 colors (8-bit or higher)

li.p: Sufficient Windows user account permission levels to:
install new software
create new folders at the C:\ directory level
JDSU recommends that the user account used for installation of the Node Manager application have the highest (administrator) privilege levels on the computer.

body.p: Using the Java Web Start (JWS) version of Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager requires a web server (such as Webserver Tomcat 6.0 or higher) on the host system. The system requirements are those of the web server.
In addition to the standard system requirements, the client requirements for running the JWS Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager are:

li.p: A web browser running Internet Explorer 7.0 or higher, or Firefox 3.5.2 or higher.
The Java Web Start plug-in for the browser, JRE 1.6 or higher (64 bit for Internet Explorer on Windows 7).
li.note: If using Windows Vista, a default browser for Java Web Start must be registered. Refer to Registering JWS Browsers for Vista for details on how to register all applicable browsers.

li.p: The URL for the JWS Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager.

note.p: Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager supports both IPv4 and IPv6 addressing. If using IPv6 addressing for the JWS URL, the IPv6 hexadecimal section of the URL should be enclosed in square brackets, for example as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/.

body.p: This section describes the steps required to install the Multi-Node Manager application.
This section contains the following topics and procedures:

li.xref: Installing Node Manager for Windows on page 3-3
Installing JWS Node Manager on page 3-5
Registering JWS Browsers for Vista on page 3-8

body.p: WaveReady Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager should be installed on the computer that will access and manage the WaveReady network, nodes and modules.

It is important to note that BOTH WaveReady Multi-Node Manager and WaveReady Node Manager can be installed on the same computer; each application downloads to a separate directory folder and creates a separate desktop shortcut.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to install the WaveReady Multi-Node Manager (WRMNM) or WaveReady Node Manager (WRNM) software.

note.p: During upgrades of WRMNM and WRNM, the installer automatically uninstalls the existing version before installing the new version.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: Ensure that the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager software folder is available to the computer that will host and run the application.
Ensure that the minimum system requirements are met.

note.p: The Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager release files are in default directories on the product CD-ROM. For information on the CD-ROM content see the current release notes.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: When installing Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager, take note of the following conditions:

li.p: Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager can not be installed in a directory that contains more than 127 characters, including the drive name and directory (backslash) dividers.

Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager can not be installed in a directory that contains non-Latin characters (also known as Roman characters). For example, the directory path can not contain Cyrillic characters.
An FTP error may occur when a directory containing spaces or invalid characters is used. Ensure that the directory path does not contain spaces or the following invalid characters.

section.p: When upgrading, choose the same directory where the existing Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager version is installed. This enables the installer to uninstall the previous version prior to installing the new version.

step.cmd: Browse to the \NodeMgr\Software\Node_Manager_Installer directory on the release CD. This directory may also be copied to the computer that will host and run the application.
Double-click install.cmd in the Installer folder.
In the WaveReady Node Manager Installer window, click Yes to continue with the installation.
In the WaveReady License Agreement window, read the license agreement and then click I Accept to continue.
In the Installation Configuration window, accept the default installation directory (C:\WaveReady_Node_Manager ) or browse to select another directory.
To create a desktop shortcut for Node Manager, select the Create Desktop Shortcut option and click Next.
If there is an earlier Node Manager version installed and a message appears confirming an uninstall, click Yes.

In the Installation Confirmation window, confirm the installation conditions (the Installation Directory, any Uninstall and Create Desktop Shortcut) then click Next to install Node Manager with the specified defaults. The dialog box shows the progress of the installation.
When the installation finishes, click Next and then click Exit. A desktop shortcut will appear. See Launching Node Manager on page 3-10 to launch Node Manager.

body.p: The Java Web Start (JWS) Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager application must be installed on the system where the web server is running.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to install the Java Web Start (JWS) Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager application.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: The Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager release files are in default directories on the product CD-ROM. For information on the CD-ROM content see the current release notes.
If using Windows Vista, a default browser for Java Web Start must be registered. See the following instructions for details on how to register all applicable browsers.
If using IPv6 addressing for the hostname of theJWS Node Manager URL, the IPv6 hexadecimal hostname should be enclosed in square brackets, for example as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Configure the web server to serve.jnlp files.

info.p: For example, if using Apache 2.2, add the following line to the mime.type file located in \Apache Software Foundation\Apache2.2\conf:

note.p: Restart the web server if required to put the change into effect.

step.cmd: In the Release CD directory, unpack WaveReady_Multi-Node_ Manager_JWS_Installer.zip or WaveReady_Node_ Manager_JWS_Installer.zip into the Web Server DocumentRoot folder.

info.p: The web server DocumentRoot depends on the location of the Web Server installation.

When the package is expanded, make sure to select the options, if applicable, to reproduce the directory structure. This is required to recreate the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager folder structure.

step.cmd: Go to the \jws folder located within the DocumentRoot folder where the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager folder was installed.
In the \jws folder, copy these two files and remove the .pp extension from the copies: download.html.pp>download.htmldownload.jnlp.pp>download.jnlp
In the download.html file use Wordpad or Notepad to change the strings “hostname” and “httpport” to the web server hostname and port.

info.p: If the web server uses the default port 80, it is not necessary to specify a port number.
If using IPv6 addressing for the hostname, it should be enclosed in square brackets, for example, as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/

step.cmd: In the download.jnlp file, change the strings “hostname” and “httpport” to the web server hostname and port.

info.p: If the web server uses the default port 80, it is not necessary to specify a port number.
If using IPv6 addressing for the hostname, it should be enclosed in square brackets, for example, as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/

step.cmd: Enter this URL in the browser to test the Node Manager launching process: http://hostname:portnumber/index.html

info.p: If using IPv6 addressing for the hostname, it should be enclosed in square brackets, for example, as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/
A web server must be running.

step.cmd: Click the Launch button to launch Node Manager.

info.p: The following information window will display.

stepresult.p: After JWS downloads the application, a Security Warning message displays, confirming the application's access to the machine and network.

step.cmd: Press Run to start Node Manager.

body.p: If using Windows Vista, a default browser for Java Web Start must be registered.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to register a default Java browser (or browsers) when running Windows Vista.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: This procedure has no special requirements.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: If Java is installed on a computer running Windows Vista Operating System (OS), follow these instructions to open the Java Control Panel:,

substep.cmd: 32 bit Windows Vista OS: Open the Control Panel and double-click the Java icon.
64 bit Windows Vista OS: Open the Control Panel, double-click the View 32 bit Control Panel icon, then double-click the Java icon.

stepresult.p: The Java Control Panel will open.

step.cmd: Select the Advanced tab and expand the tree view under Settings.

info.p: The following illustration shows the the Java Control Panel with the Advanced tab selected.

step.cmd: Expand the "Default Java for browsers" tree and ensure that all the required browsers for JWS are selected.
Save the changes.
Verify that the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager application will launch on an appropriate browser through Java Web Start.

body.p: Consult this section to launch Node Manager, once it is installed in the computer that will be used to access and manage the node.
This section contains the following topics:

li.xref: Limits on Account Usage on page 3-10
TL1Force Password Change on First Login on page 3-13
Launching Node Manager for Windows on page 3-13
Launching JWS Node Manager on page 3-15

body.p: When mounted in the WaveReady shelf, the COM-200 module performs a system test and check for internal hardware errors during initialization. The COM-200 module is initialized with two default user accounts:

ul.li: Default superuser account using the backplance EEPROM with default user identification and password. The User ID (TL1 parameter <uid>) is SUPERUSER and the password (TL1 parameter <pid>) is Sup%9User.

Default administrator account on the module itself (and therefore configurable) with default user identification and password. The User ID (TL1 parameter <uid>) is ADMINUSER and the password (TL1 parameter <pid>) is Admin%9.

body.p: Take note of the following limitations when creating a new user account:

li.p: Each COM-200 supports a maximum of twelve (12) user accounts, including the ADMINUSER account. There is, therefore, a maximum of eleven (11) administrator-created user accounts available. Attempts to exceed these user account limits will be blocked and an ACCOUNTS EXCEEDED dialog will display.

note.p: The SUPERUSER account is not included in this limitation.

li.p: JDSU recommends that the SUPERUSER account be reserved for administrative tasks, such as registering new users on the network, monitoring the number of active sessions, closing a user session and deleting a user account.
JDSU recommends using the ADMINUSER account for node and network administrative tasks, and an administrator-created user account for equipment configuration and management tasks.

Each COM-200 supports a maximum of five (5) logins with the same userid (including the SUPERUSER account), and a maximum of ten (10) logins with different userids (any combination of different and identical userids totalling ten, including the SUPERUSER account). Attempts to exceed these login limits will be blocked and an ACCESS DENIED dialog will display.
If access is denied because the login limit for the COM-200 has been exceeded, one or more sessions should be terminated;
An account with administration privileges can terminate a user session,
An ADMINUSER account can terminate a SUPERUSER account and a user session, and
A user session can terminate itself.

body.p: If a Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager session is left open and inactive, the application will "time out."
This time-out feature preserves memory, prevents memory-related problems which may affect the application, and reduces access problems related to user session limits on nodes.
The software defines an inactive period as a period without any user commands sent to the node.
Time-out rules apply to all users: ADMINUSER, SUPERUSER and any other new administrator-created user account. These time-out defaults apply:

li.p: By default, Node Manager (WRNM) will logout all inactive users after 25 minutes of inactivity, unless a software download is in progress.
After 25 minutes of inactivity, the Application Connection Lost dialog box will automatically display a warning message and three options: Restart, Work Offline and Exit.
By default, Multi-Node Manager (WRMNM) will logout all inactive users after 48 hours (2880 minutes) of inactivity.
A warning dialog, giving a five minute grace period, will display a warning message after 48 hours with two options: Continue and Logout.

note.p: There is a limit of five (5) user sessions per node. If this maximum is reached, and one or more of those sessions are inactive, additional users will not be able to log-in. Disabling the time-out feature may result in user access problems.

context.p: Use this procedure to change the time-out parameters, or disable the feature by editing the properties field of the application short-cut.

step.cmd: Locate the desktop shortcut for Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager.
Right-click the shortcut. A pop-up menu displays.
Select Properties from the pop-up menu. A Properties dialog displays.
Select the Shortcut tab in the Properties dialog. The Target field displays the directory path location of the application.
Scroll, if necessary, to the right to the end of this directory path.
Type “ timeout=x”, where “x” is the number of minutes before the application will time-out. Setting the timeout value to “0” will disable the feature; there will be no forced logout of users.

substep.cmd: Enter a single space between the directory path and “timeout”.

topic.title: TL1Force Password Change on First Login

body.p: Take note of the following password conditions and limitations:

li.p: If this is the first launch of a new Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager installation by a network administrator, enter the default user ID “SUPERUSER” and the default password “Sup%9User” OR the default user ID “ADMINUSER” and password “Admin%9” into the User Authentication fields.
If this is the first launch by a new user account, enter the user name and password assigned by the network administrator.

ol.li:
If enabled, the TL1 Force Password Change on First Login feature will then prompt for a new password, chosen by the user.
This feature is enabled or disabled by selecting the appropriate radio button on the Node-Specific Properties panel. This feature is configured by the system administrator on the communications module (COM-200) of each node.
The default setting for TL1 Force Password Change on First Login is Disabled. When a user account is created, or changed while TL1 Force Password Change on First Login is enabled, the feature will prompt the user to change their password, from the password chosen by the administrator to a user-chosen password, each time:
a new user account logs on for the first time to a node, or
an existing user account with a new administrator-assigned password logs on for the first time to a node
This new password prompt will appear as each new node connection is opened. The new user-chosen password must be entered to complete the connection.
If the network includes several nodes, this repeated TL1 Force Password Change on First Login and re-entry from the password chosen by the administrator to the user-chosen password may be onerous. For this reason, TL1 Force Password Change on First Login may be left at its default setting of Disabled.
Even if TL1 Force Password Change on First Login is Disabled, JDSU recommends changing the administrator-assigned password to a more secure user-chosen password during the first user account launch.

body.p: Node Manager must be launched before beginning the commissioning process.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to launch the WRNM Connect To Node window.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: The computer used to host Node Manager sessions must meet these minimum system requirements:

li.p: Pentium III or better (600 MHz or better)
128 MB of RAM (256 preferred)
65 MB of available hard-disk space
Display set to 1024 x 768 pixels (or more) and 256 colors (8-bit or higher)
Supported Windows operating system.
Sufficient Windows user account permission levels to:
install new software
create new folders at the C:\ directory level
JDSU recommends that the user account used for installation of the Node Manager application have the highest (administrator) privilege levels on the computer.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: On the desktop, double-click the WaveReady Node Manager shortcut, or
In the Node Manager directory (default is C:\WaveReady_ Node_Manager), double-click startNodeManager. bat .

stepresult.p: The Node Manager Connect To Node dialog box appears.

fig.title: Node Manager Connect To Node dialog

step.cmd: Proceed to the appropriate procedure:

substep.cmd: Procedure: Connecting to a WaveReady Node
Procedure: Re-Connecting to a Node after a Lost Connection

body.p: JWS enables the launching of Node Manager from a remote PC; a computer other than the application host machine.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to launch JWS Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: The URL to the JWS Node Manager on the host system is required.

body.section: If using Windows Vista, a default browser for Java Web Start must be registered.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Enter the URL to the JWS Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager host in the browser locator field.

info.p: If using IPv6 addressing for the hostname of the JWS Node Manager URL, the IPv6 hexadecimal hostname should be enclosed in square brackets, for example as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/

stepresult.p: A page with a yellow panel and a Launch button should display.

step.cmd: Click the Launch button to launch Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager.

stepresult.p: After the application downloads, a Security Warning message displays confirming the application's access to the machine and network.

step.cmd: Press Run to start Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager.
When the Node Manager Open Session dialog box appears, enter the connection parameters for the desired node and click Connect.

info.p: If this is the first launch of a new install, use the factory default user name: SUPERUSER and the factory default password: Sup%9User to login. However, JDSU strongly recommends changing the user name and password once Node Manager is running.

body.p: This section contains troubleshooting information related to Node Manager upgrades.
This section contains the following topics:

li.xref: Troubleshooting Installation Errors on page 3-17
Troubleshooting WRNM Connectivity on page 3-18
Troubleshoot JWS Launch on page 3-18
Troubleshooting Node Upgrades on page 3-18
Troubleshooting Software Upgrade on page 3-19
Viewing Online Help without Launching Node Manager on page 3-20
Uninstalling WRNM for Windows on page 3-20

body.p: The Windows operating system supports the setting of user permission levels to regulate and control a user’s ability to install or de-install software on a computer and create folders at the C:\ directory level.

Since installing Multi-Node Manager and Node Manager requires both the installing of the application software and the creation of an application folder at the C:\ directory level, an installation will fail if the user permission level on the target computer is not high enough, and an “unexpected error” dialog will display.
If this occurs, click OK, exit the installation procedure and contact the system administrator to increase the user permission levels on the target computer.
JDSU recommends that the user account used for installation of the Node Manager application have the highest (administrator) privilege levels on the computer.
WaveReady Node Manager connects to the Craft Terminal of a node's COM-200 module through TCP port 3082.
If unable to connect to a node, check that TCP port 3082 is accessible from WRNM.

WaveReady Node Manager Java Web Start (JWS) allows management sessions using a web browser. If Node Manager JWS will not launch, check that the computer used to launch Node Manager JWS has these programs installed and that following conditions are met:

ul.li: A web server (such as Webserver Tomcat 6.0 or higher) on the host system. The system requirements are those of the web server.
A web browser running Internet Explorer 7.0 or higher, or Firefox 3.5.2 or higher.

The Java Web Start plug-in for the browser, JRE 1.6 or higher.
If using Windows Vista, a default browser for Java Web Start must be registered. See Registering JWS Browsers for Vista on page 3-8 for details on how to register all applicable browsers.

The URL for the JWS Node Manager.
Node Manager supports both IPv4 and IPv6 addressing. If using IPv6 addressing for the JWS Node Manager URL, the IPv6 hexadecimal section of the URL should be enclosed in square brackets, for example as follows: http://[2200::a0d:9905]:8080/WRNM/.

body.p: WaveReady Node Manager acts as an FTP server; the WaveReady Craft Terminal acts as an FTP client in FTP passive mode. To support the above FTP situation, the routers, firewalls and web content filters must be configured so that:

ul.li: WRNM FTP server TCP port 21 is accessible from any TCP port of the Craft Terminal (TCP port > 1023)
WRNM FTP server TCP port > 1023 is accessible from any TCP port of the Craft Terminal (TCP port > 1023)
Web content filters allow FTP http based format in the copy rfile sent from WRNM to the Craft Terminal

section.p: An FTP error may occur when a directory containing spaces or invalid characters is used. Ensure that the directory meets the following requirements:

li.p: Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager can not be installed in a directory that contains more than 127 characters, including the drive name and directory (backslash) dividers.

Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager can not be installed in a directory that contains non-Latin characters (also known as Roman characters). For example, the directory path can not contain Cyrillic characters.
An FTP error may occur when a directory containing spaces or invalid characters is used. Ensure that the directory path does not contain spaces or the following invalid characters.

body.p: For a software upgrade to succeed, both the upgrade version and the existing software version must be correctly identified in a standard format. Node Manager requires that the “REV” number have three digits.
For example, both:
will return the following dialog warning:

fig.title: Invalid Hardware Rev. Number Warning Dialog

body.p: To force the node to continue with the upgrade, click “Yes”. Since the results may be unexpected, and the whole upgrade may fail, JDSU does not recommend forcing the upgrade under these conditions.
To continue the upgrade, skipping the upgrade for this module, click “No”. This is the recommended action.

topic.title: Viewing Online Help without Launching Node Manager

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to view the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager Online Help without launching the application.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: Online Help can not be accessed remotely without launching the application. Therefore, Node Manager must be installed on the PC used to view Online Help.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: Browse to the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager directory.
Double-click HelpViewer.bat.

stepresult.p: The viewer opens and displays the Multi-Node Manager or Node Manager Help files.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: Use this procedure to uninstall Node Manager software from a computer.

note.p: For upgrades it is NOT necessary to uninstall the existing version. The installer will automatically uninstall it before performing the upgrade.

section.title: Requirements
section.p: If WRNM is connected to any systems, ensure that it is disconnected before uninstalling WRNM.

section.title: Precautions
section.p: This procedure has no special precautions.

step.cmd: If the WRNM software was installed from a CD ROM, browse to the directory where the WRNM is installed. The default installation directory is C:\ WaveReady_Node_Manager.
Delete the installation directory.
Delete the shortcut (if one was created using the installer).
